preposition.description: Expressing the situation of something that is or appears to be enclosed or surrounded by something else.
examples: dressed in their Sunday best
she saw it in the rearview mirror
living in Deep River
soak it in warm soapy water

preposition.description: Expressing a period of time during which an event takes place or a situation remains the case.
examples: they met in 1885
at one o'clock in the morning
I hadn't seen him in years

preposition.description: Expressing the length of time before a future event is expected to take place.
examples: I'll see you in fifteen minutes

preposition.description: (often followed by a noun without a determiner) expressing a state or condition.
examples: to be in love
I've got to put my affairs in order
a woman in her thirties
laid out in a straight line
I read it in a book
acting in a film
she works in publishing

preposition.description: Indicating the language or medium used.
examples: say it in Polish
put it in writing

preposition.description: As an integral part of (an activity)
examples: in planning public expenditure it is better to be prudent

adverb.description: Expressing movement with the result that someone or something becomes enclosed or surrounded by something else.
examples: come in
presently the admiral breezed in
bring it in

adverb.description: Expressing the situation of being enclosed or surrounded by something.
examples: we were locked in
the train got in very late

adverb.description: (of the tide) rising or at its highest level.
(of an infielder or outfielder) playing closer to home plate than usual.
examples: looking for a force, they brought the infield in

adjective.description: (of a person) present at one's home or office.
examples: we knocked at the door but there was no one in
pastels and light colors are in this year
the in thing to do

adjective.description: (of the ball in tennis and similar games) landing within the designated playing area.

noun.description: A position of influence with someone powerful or famous.
examples: he would ensure an in with the nominee

phrases: it looks as if we're in for a storm
These fine visitors, I thought, were in for what I can only describe as a culinary comeuppance.
However, the two of them were in for quite a startling surprise.
CBI members must have known what they were in for when they elected him.
Anyone who buys this album expecting gentle country wailing will be in for the rudest of shocks.
origin: Old English in (preposition), inn, inne (adverb), of Germanic origin; related to Dutch and German in (preposition), German ein (adverb), from an Indo-European root shared by Latin in and Greek en.
